narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob Fetter
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob and Lia both worked very hard to make the class run smoothly. I worked closely with Rob and found that he was very professional.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Robert Fetter was an incredible help and was always available and quick to challenge and be receptive to our ideas.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  I interacted mostly with Rob Fetter.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob Fetter

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Rob was an excellent resource and I can't recommend him enough to teach a course like this in the future.
I will be providing direct feedback to the instructor and TAs of this course on my own, and with my working group.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Working with great people/organizations.Enthusiastic classmatesHelpful professorAbility to travel to an incredible conference related to a subject I enjoy and am passionate about.
The opportunity to expose students to organizations and conferences that are relevant to our respective future careers.
The ability to lead our own project.

The opportunity to work with an international organization and to attend an international conference makes this a tremendously valuable class. Aspects of the class structured around the conference and client-based work were very useful. However, the great variety of guest lecturers on international environmental law and policy, negotiation, and NGOs were also fascinating and probably equally useful to my career development.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Classes ran out of steam towards the end of the semester.

The administrative aspect of handling reimbursements. If the travel of the students is suppose to be secured with supporting funds, then there shouldn't be any reimbursement after the travel necessary. It seems that there is that possibility of costs not being covered even while students have already signified the organization they intend to work with. Granted that students may have exceeded in the budget presented, there should be guiding rules on how much the budget should be given limitations of the funds and not the other way around. Considering that reimbursement in Yale University is such a tedious process, comparable to how government probably handles such procedures, and given how some students depend on scholarship to make it through, the money that needs be reimbursed, affects the available funds a student may need at any given time. I hope that is recognized.

There was a discrepancy between the project/field trip and the course information. At times the course/lectures felt irrelevant to our project. Perhaps having more continuity between the specific projects and the lectures. (Though I know this year was experimental with the variety of field trips.)

The class had way too much going on at all times. It was both an academic class, with weekly readings and assigned written responses, as well as a client-based "clinic" involving a substantial client-based project and several class assignments to report on the client work. Additionally, there were a number of required out-of-class activities, including a two-day negotiation exercise (on a weekend). Furthermore, each group was responsible for planning their own trip and making all conference arrangements, which was very time consuming. As a result of spending so much time on all of the non-client aspects of the class, I do not feel that I contributed enough work and hours to the stakeholder organization.In addition to having more in-class and out-of-class time to work on the client project, the class would have benefited from a better application process. The application process was not successful at weeding out people who were not serious about doing stakeholder work. It was demoralizing to see other members of my group spend so little effort and time on the stakeholder projects. I think that the description of the stakeholder projects presented before students apply should include themajor deliverables that will be expected so that students have a clear idea of the work involved before they apply for the class.This was probably the most valuable class that I took this semester because of the "real world" component, but other elements should be scaled back.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There are no lab/discussion sections for this course.

As stated above, the class could be improved by having a stronger focus on the stakeholder work. The lectures were very valuable, however, and I would suggest devoting just a few more classes to discussion and work on the stakeholder projects.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Rob did a tremendous job at bringing in lecturers and coordinating all of the class logistics, not an easy task! He did a fantastic job at communicating with us throughout the semester via Classes.V2 and email about readings, deadlines, etc. There were many updates to the syllabus as the class evolved, and he did a great job at incorporating our feedback and making sure that the course tracked student interests.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Needed to ease up and not be so uptight and rigid about aspects of the class (as almost all PhD TF's do).

Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob Fetter is well-versed in the ins and outs of international conferences, particularly the one that I attended. He has a broad knowledge of the various topics on the course and was able to contribute to the discussion through the questions he himself raised, as well as his incites on many topics.He was able to give a sense of organization to the different topics as well even if some topics were seemingly handled on the fly. At some point in the curse, students were asked what other topics they felt were relevant, which I felt shouldn't have been necessary since this was not a course that was being given for the first time. However, Rob was able to present the matter in such a way that made the opportunity very useful to expand beyond what was already being offered in the class.Rob accounted for himself very well in the course.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob is a great teacher and very dedicated to the students.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: FES 850 gave me an opportunity to understand how the research I am doing is being discussed at the international level where the policies that are applicable are being shaped.
Perfectly. It was wonderful being able to lead a project and have the support of the class.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Related to my interests, opportunity to work with great people and travel

The conference I attended is relevant to the research I am conducting. It also gave me an opportunity to work with an organization I admire and was pleasantly surprised at how the organization has been able to go beyond what we normally associate as its work.
To lead a project on climate change and winter sports.

I took this course for the opportunity to work with an organization relevant to my career interests and for the opportunity to attend an international conference. Learning about international law and policy was a secondary interest that motivated me to take this course.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
The knowledge is very useful in the future and I look forward to attending similar conferences in the future. The potential of the course for student exposure is huge.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Sometimes you get people you work well with, sometimes you don't. I had a mix. But we made it work, and I learned a lot of good things and had great experiences all and all.
My group is fantastic.

The main advantages were learning from everyone's experience and knowledge, particularly while traveling and during the conference. The main disadvantage was that most group members were not enthusiastic about the stakeholder project and were not motivated to take on a leadership role in communicating with the stakeholder and organizing our work.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Have an organization they intend to work with even before the class. If the organization is already among the organizations that have agreed to work with students in the course, then be able to communicate with them regularly throughout the course of the semester. If its a new organization, be definite about the kind of work the student intends to do. Communication with the stakeholder organization is very important.
Take it if you want to lead an independent project that involves a field trip.

First, ask lots of questions at the beginning (in the first class) and know what you are getting into. This class is a lot of work, especially if you devote the appropriate amount of time to the stakeholder project and conference planning. Also, make sure you are enthusiastic about the stakeholder you are working with and that your group members are equally enthusiastic. Do what you can to inspire and motivate your group members to do excellent work for the stakeholder (this is something that I could have done a better job at). Expect to work hard at the conference--and you'll have a great time!
